name: Stablecoins V3
author: El Genio Tokenio
description: Comprehensive attestation recipe for USD stablecoins, informed by the SVB crisis failure modes identified in Zach Zukowski's MVEP framework. Covers what a stablecoin SHOULD attest to — both what issuers typically provide and what was found missing when USDC de-pegged in March 2023.

attestationTypes.note: Core stablecoin promise: 1 token = 1 USD redeemable
Proof of reserves — the minimum bar
Third-party verification (e.g. Deloitte, Grant Thornton) — issuer self-reporting is not enough
What are the reserves made of? T-bills vs bank deposits vs repos matters enormously under stress
SVB missing artifact: Circle had $3.3B (8% of reserves) at one bank. Concentration was not salient in disclosures
Which banks/custodians hold the reserves? Circle disclosed partners but not mechanics
SVB missing artifact: whether Circle's deposits qualified for pass-through insurance was unknown. Per-custodian segregation model needed
Each reserve custodian should be regulated — FDIC-insured bank, OCC-chartered, etc.
Are reserves being lent, pledged, or used in repo? Must be explicit
Issuer must hold appropriate licenses (money transmitter, e-money, etc.)
For stablecoins, on-chain is typically the ownership record
SVB lesson: monthly cadence is insufficient. Crisis moved in hours. Must define crisis-cadence protocol
Technical finality definition. But Zach warns: block finality ≠ economic finality
Factual claim about freeze/blacklist capability — risk committees need to know either way
Whether the token is permissionless ERC-20. Most stablecoins are (except for blacklisted addresses)
SVB missing artifact: 'am I a creditor of Circle? What's my priority?' No holder knew for 48 hours
SVB missing artifact: what happens to reserves if a custodian (bank) is seized? The core SVB question
If Circle goes bankrupt, are reserves protected from Circle's creditors?
SVB exposed: USDC holder was unsecured creditor of Circle, not direct claimant on reserves
SVB missing artifact: 'disclosures didn't make the risk salient: that a single partner's failure could break the peg entirely'
Zach's question #5: top 3 dependencies (custodian, oracle, gateway) and their triggers
SVB: USDC holders bore the depeg loss (temporarily). Loss allocation was undefined
Zach: single-signer admin keys are disqualifying. Minimum 3-of-5 for stablecoin admin ops
Zach: 'evidence of exercise, not just existence' — every admin action must have on-chain audit trail
Independent smart contract audit with no critical findings
Issuer's financial statements audited per GAAS/IFRS
